statics.name: isAbbreviation
statics.description: Returns true if 'input' is an abbreviation

returns.desc: true if 'input' is an abbreviation

statics.name: isQuestion
statics.description: Returns true if sentence starts with a question word

returns.desc: true if 'sentence' starts with a question word

statics.name: isPunctuation
statics.description: Returns true if every character of 'text' is a punctuation character

returns.desc: true or false

statics.name: analyze
statics.description: Computes a set of features for the object, including phonemes, syllables, stresses, and part-of-speech

parameters.desc:
options (optional)

{boolean} options.simple:
use WordNet style tags or not, default=false

{boolean} options.silent:
silent LTS or not (only in JavaScript, default=false)

{boolean} options.inline:
inline tags or not (only in JavaScript, default=false)

returns.desc: keys are [ phones, stresses, syllables, pos, tokens]

statics.name: randomSeed
statics.description: Sets the seed for RiTa's random number generator

statics.name: randomOrdering
statics.description:
Returns a randomly ordered array of unique integers from 0 to numElements.
The size of the array will be numElements.

parameters.type:
int
(or an array, this option not available in Java yet)
parameters.desc:
numElements
(or an array to randomly re-order, this option not available in Java yet)

returns.type:
int[]
(or another array if an array is used as the parameter)
returns.desc:
unique integers from 0 to numElements-1
(or the re-ordered array if an array is used as parameter)

statics.name: sentences
statics.example: RiTa.sentences(""The boy went fishing.", he said. Then he went away.");
statics.description: Splits 'text' into sentences (according to PENN Treebank conventions)

parameters.desc: regex (optional) the pattern to be used for word tokenization

optional way to set the regex

{String} option.pattern:
the regex to use

returns.desc: array of sentences

statics.name: addTransform
statics.description: Registers a new RiScript transform function that may then be used in all RiScript evaluations (including within Grammars)

parameters.desc: the function to call, which should accept and return a string

statics.name: evaluate
statics.example:
RiTa.evaluate("He was (happy | sad | indifferent)");
RiTa.evaluate("He was (happy | sad | \$emo)", context);
statics.description: Parses and executes a RiScript string

parameters.desc: the context for any referenced variables or functions (optional)

returns.desc: the result of the evaluation

statics.name: tokenize
statics.description:
Tokenizes a string (into words) according to Penn Treebank conventions
See: ftp://ftp.cis.upenn.edu/pub/treebank/public_html/tokenization.html

parameters.desc: regex (optional) the pattern to be used for tokenization

returns.desc: in which each element is a single token (or word)

statics.name: untokenize
statics.description:
Joins an array (of words and punctuation) into a string, according to Penn Treebank conventions
See: ftp://ftp.cis.upenn.edu/pub/treebank/public_html/tokenization.html

returns.desc: in which the elements have been joined into a single string

statics.name: phones
statics.example:
RiTa.phones("apple"); // returns -> ae-p-ah-l

RiTa.phones("two apples"); // returns -> t-uw ae-p-ah-l-z
statics.description: Returns a string containing all phones for the input text

returns.desc:
e.g., 'ae-n eh-l-ax-f-ax-n-t ih-z ey m-ae-m-ax-l'
(for 'An elephant is a mammal')

statics.name: pos
statics.description: Uses the default PosTagger to tag the input with tags from the PENN tag set or the simplified tag set [a, r, v, n]

parameters.desc: if true, use WordNet style tags (optional, default=false)

optional way to set the option

{boolean} option.simple:
use WordNet style tag or not

returns.desc: Array of part-of-speech tags

statics.name: posInline
statics.description:
Takes an string returns a combined string of the form:

'The/dt doctor/nn treated/vbd dogs/nns'
using lowercased tags from the PENN tag set

parameters.desc: the text(or text array) to tag
use WordNet style tags or not (optional, default=false)

optional way to set the option

{boolean} option.simple:
use WordNet style tag or not, default=false

returns.desc: a combined string of words and pos tags

statics.name: stresses
statics.description: Analyzes the input and returns a new string containing the stresses for each syllable of the input text

returns.desc: e.g., '1/0/1', with 1's meaning 'stressed', and 0's meaning 'unstressed',

statics.name: syllables
statics.description: Analyzes the input and returns a string containing the phonemes for each syllable of each word of the input text,  delimited by dashes (phonemes) and spaces (words)

returns.desc: e.g., 'dh-ax d-ao-g r-ae-n f-ae-s-t' for the 4 syllables of the phrase 'The dog ran fast'

statics.name: concordance
statics.example:
// Java

opts = new HashMap();
opts.put("ignoreCase", false);
opts.put("ignoreStopWords", true);

result = RiTa.concordance(text, word, opts);
// or RiTa.concordance(text, opts);
// which will return a list of all words in the text


// JavaScript

opts = {
ignoreCase: false,
ignoreStopWords: true
};

result = RiTa.concordance(text, opts);
statics.description: Creates a concordance, a list of words with their frequency of occurence, from the given text and (optional) options

parameters.desc: the word to lookup (not available in JavaScript)

options (optional) the relevant options for the KWIK model:

{int} options.wordCount:
# of words of context on either side of input word

{boolean} options.ignoreCase:
Ignore upper/lower case in the model

{boolean} options.ignoreStopWords:
Ignore words like 'the', 'and', 'a', 'of', etc, as specified in RiTa.STOP_WORDS

{boolean} options.ignorePunctuation:
Ignore punctuation tokens in the model

{String[]} options.wordsToIgnore:
A set of words (alternative stop-words, for example) to ignore.

returns.desc: the concordance

statics.name: kwic
statics.example:
// Java: API not available yet


// JavaScript

let opts = {
ignoreCase: false,
ignoreStopWords: true
};

RiTa.concordance(text, opts);
let lines = RiTa.kwic(word, numWords);
statics.description:
Return a list of occurrences of the key word in the Key-Word-In-Context (KWIC) model.
RiTa.concordance() must called before calling kwic().
Note : this API is not available in Java yet

parameters.desc: upper limit of words before or after the keyword in the returned sentences. (optional, default=6)

returns.desc: all the occurrences of the keyword in the model, each with no more than 'numWords' words of context on either side

statics.name: conjugate
statics.example:
// JavaScript

opts = {
tense: RiTa.PRESENT,
number: RiTa.SINGULAR,
person: RiTa.THIRD
};

result = RiTa.conjugate('swim', opts);


// Java

opts = new HashMap();
opts.put("tense", RiTa.PAST);
opts.put("number", RiTa.PLURAL);
opts.put("person", RiTa.FIRST);

result = RiTa.conjugate("swim", opts);
statics.description: Conjugates the 'verb' according to the specified options

parameters.desc:
object containing the relevant options (tense, number, person...) for the conjugator

{int} options.tense:
[RiTa.PAST, RiTa.PRESENT, or RiTa.FUTURE]

{int} options.number:
[RiTa.SINGULAR or RiTa.PLURAL]

{int} options.person:
[RiTa.FIRST, RiTa.SECOND or RiTa.THIRD]

{int} options.form:
[RiTa.INFINITIVE or RiTa.GERUND]

{boolean} options.passive

{boolean} options.progressive

{boolean} options.interrogative

{boolean} options.perfect

returns.desc: the conjugated verb

statics.name: pastParticiple
statics.description: Returns the past participle form of the verb

returns.desc: the past participle form of the verb

statics.name: presentParticiple
statics.description: Returns the present participle form of the verb

returns.desc: the present participle form of the verb

statics.name: stem
statics.description: Extracts base roots from a word according to the Pling stemming algorithm

returns.desc: the stemmed form of the word

statics.name: pluralize
statics.description: Pluralizes a noun according to pluralization rules

parameters.desc:
option for pluralization (optional)

{boolean} option.dbug: if true, output debug log to console

returns.desc: the (regular or irregular) plural form of the noun

statics.name: singularize
statics.description: Singularize a word according to singularization rules

parameters.desc:
option for singularization (optional)

{boolean} option.dbug: if true, output debug log to console

returns.desc: the singular form of the noun

statics.name: hasWord
statics.description: Returns true if the word exists in the lexicon (case-insensitive)

returns.desc: true if the current lexicon includes the word, else false

statics.name: alliterations
statics.description: Finds alliterations by comparing the phonemes of the input string to those of each word in the lexicon

parameters.desc:
options (optional)

{int} options.minLength:
minimum number of characters in target word (default=3)

{int} options.maxLength:
maximum number of characters in target word

{int} options.numSyllables:
target # of syllables in the word

{int} options.limit:
maximum # of results to return

{String} options.pos:
target part-of-speech for the word
either from the PENN tag set or the simplified tag set [a, r, v, n]

returns.desc: array of alliterations

statics.name: randomWord
statics.example:
// a random word from the lexicon
RiTa.randomWord();

// a random plural noun from the lexicon
RiTa.randomWord({ targetPos: "nns"});

// a random word with 3 syllables and length 3 or 4
RiTa.randomWord({ numSyllables: 3, maxLength: 4});
statics.description: Returns a random word from the lexicon according to specified options
statics.syntax:
RiTa.randomWord()
RiTa.randomWord(opts);
//in Java you can also do below
//which allow you to set options without Map
RiTa.randomWord(syllables);
RiTa.randomWord(pos);
RiTa.randomWord(pos, syllables);

parameters.desc:
options (optional)

{int} options.minLength:
minimum number of characters in target word (default=4)

{int} options.maxLength:
maximum number of characters in target word

{int} options.numSyllables:
target # of syllables in the word

{String} options.targetPos:
target part-of-speech for the word
either from the PENN tag set or the simplified tag set [a, r, v, n]

returns.desc: the random word

statics.name: rhymes
statics.description: Two words are considered as rhyming if their final stressed vowel and all following phonemes are identical

parameters.desc:
options (optional)

{int} options.minLength:
minimum number of characters in target word

{int} options.maxLength:
maximum number of characters in target word

{int} options.numSyllables:
target # of syllables in the word

{int} options.limit:
maximum # of results to return

{String} options.targetPos:
target part-of-speech for the word
either from the PENN tag set or the simplified tag set [a, r, v, n]

returns.desc: rhymes for the word, or an empty array if none are found

statics.name: search
statics.description: Searches for words in the lexicon that match the given criteria, either by phoneme, stress, or letters. If no regex or options are supplied, the full set of words is returned.

parameters.desc:
options (optional)

{int} options.minLength:
minimum number of characters in target word (default=3)

{int} options.maxLength:
maximum number of characters in target word

{int} options.numSyllables:
target # of syllables in the word

{int} options.limit:
maximum # of results to return

{String} options.type:
use "stresses" to indicate that the regex is for stresses match
use "phones" to indicate that the regex is for phonemes match

{String} options.pos:
target part-of-speech for the word
either from the PENN tag set or the simplified tag set [a, r, v, n]

returns.desc: array of words matching the search criteria in the lexicon (or all words if no criteria is provided)

statics.name: isAdverb
statics.description: Returns true if the word has an adverb form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of an adverb in the PENN tag set (e.g. rb, rbr, rbs)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as an adverb

statics.name: isNoun
statics.description: Returns true if the word has a noun form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of a noun in the PENN tag set(e.g. nn, nns, nnp, nnps)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as a noun

statics.name: isVerb
statics.description: Returns true for if word has a verb form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of a verb in the PENN tag set (e.g. vb, vbg, vbd, vbp, vbz)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as a verb

statics.name: isStopWord
statics.description:
Returns true if the word is a 'stop word', a commonly used word that is often ignored in text processing. To use your own list, simply set RiTa.STOP_WORDS to a new array of words.
This API is not in Java yet

returns.desc: true if the word is a stop word, according to RiTa.STOP_WORDS

statics.name: isAdjective
statics.description: Returns true if word has an adjective form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of an adjective in the PENN tag set (e.g. jj, jjr, jjs)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as an adjective

statics.name: isAlliteration
statics.description: Returns true if the two words are alliterations (iff the first stressed consonant of the two match). Note: returns true if wordA.equals(wordB) and false if either (or both) are null.

returns.desc: true if the first stressed consonant of the two words match

statics.name: isRhyme
statics.description:
Returns true if the two words rhyme, that is, if their final stressed vowel phoneme and all following phonemes are identical, else false.

Note: returns false if word1.equals(word2) or if either (or both) are null;

parameters.desc: use letter-to-sound rules if not found in lexicon (optional, default=false)

returns.desc: true if the two words rhyme, else false.

statics.name: soundsLike
statics.example:
RiTa.soundsLike("happy");
RiTa.soundsLike("happy", { matchSpelling: true });
RiTa.soundsLike("happy", { limit: 10, minDistance: 2 });
RiTa.soundsLike("happy", { numSyllables: 2, minDistance: 2 });
RiTa.soundsLike("happy", { minWordLength:10, numSyllables:2 });
statics.description: Compares the phonemes of the input word (using a version of the Levenstein min-edit distance algorithm) to each word in the lexicon, returning the set of closest matches.

parameters.desc:
options (optional)

{bool} options.matchSpelling:
if true will also attempt to match spelling
by returning an intersection with RiTa.spellsLike (default=false)

{int} options.minLength:
minimum number of characters in target word (default=3)

{int} options.maxLength:
maximum number of characters in target word

{int} options.numSyllables:
target # of syllables in the word

{int} options.limit:
maximum # of results to return

{String} options.targetPos:
target part-of-speech for the word
either from the PENN tag set or the simplified tag set [a, r, v, n]

{int} options.minDistance:
the minimum distance of words from the target word
(increase to get more results)

returns.desc: the matching words

statics.name: spellsLike
statics.example:
RiTa.spellsLike("happy");
RiTa.spellsLike("happy", { limit: 10 });
RiTa.spellsLike("happy", { limit: 10, minDistance: 2 });
RiTa.spellsLike("happy", { numSyllables: 2, minDistance: 2 });
RiTa.spellsLike("happy", { minWordLength:10, numSyllables:2 });
statics.description: Compares the letters of the input word (using a version of the Levenstein min-edit distance algorithm) to each word in the lexicon, returning the set of closest matches.

parameters.desc:
Obejct
(or Map in Java)options (optional)

{int} options.minLength:
minimum number of characters in target word (default=3)

{int} options.maxLength:
maximum number of characters in target word

{int} options.numSyllables:
target # of syllables in the word

{int} options.limit:
maximum # of results to return

{String} options.targetPos:
target part-of-speech for the word
either from the PENN tag set or the simplified tag set [a, r, v, n]

{int} options.minDistance:
the minimum distance of words from the target word
(increase to get more results)

returns.desc: the matching words
